Award.AwardTitle: Modular Autonomous Biosampler(MAB): Multi-platform system for distinct Biological size-class sampling & preservation. Phase II-completion of standalone sampler & AUV adapte
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a serious community-wide deficiency in our ability to collect and preserve biological samples across a broad spectrum of oceanographic platforms. The PIs suggest that what is clearly needed is a single system that can be easily adapted to multiple platforms servicing a broad range of applications across the biological oceanographic community.

The PIs request funding for a 3-year development program to build and field two low-cost, high-sample capacity modular, autonomous biological sampling devices (MABs). This will include a standalone mooring-ready unit (6000 m depth rating) and a second unit adapted for a 20 cm diameter AUV. The units will be capable of filtering and preserving multiple distinct biological size classes simultaneously, and will be deployable in any aquatic setting from a variety of platform modalities (AUV, ROV, mooring, observatory node).

Broader Impacts:

The benefits of the sampler proposed herein cut across several disciplines, given the potential for acquiring multiple size fractions from a water sample. This capability will be useful from both a biological and a geological/biogeochemical perspective. In the former case, studies of zooplankton, phytoplankton, and bacterioplankton communities will be accommodated in what should be a highly efficient and cost-effective manner relative to conventional, ship-based sampling. In the future, intelligent tracking of biological features (e.g., chlorophyll patches, particulate thin layers) by AUVs will enhance the utility of such high-capacity samplers and the data generated from this material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this project we have developed and field tested a novel standalone full ocean depth modular autonomous biosampler.  This system was used during a research cruise to acquire multiple size fractions from water samples taken both manually and using triggered environmental response intelligence (smart sampling). Samples were acquired throughout the water column allowing users to gather samples from both a biological and a geological/biogeochemical perspective. In the former case, studies of zooplankton, phytoplankton, and bacterioplankton communities will be accommodated in what should be a highly efficient and cost-effective manner relative to conventional, ship-based sampling. This stand-alone 600 m rated sampler is now availible for further use and testing by the oceanographic community and can be operated from a cable or battery powered mooring configuration.  In the future, intelligent tracking of biological features (e.g., chlorophyll patches, particulate thin layers) by will enhance the utility of such high-capacity samplers and the data generated from this material.

Not only has this project resulted in the development and testing of a stand-alone working biosampler but through our development partner (Cellula Robotics) we have established a patent and a commercial product line that has already resulted in 2 second generation units that were built and a continued commercial licensing agreement to make further units available to users. 

In addition to the lab and cruise testing this project has resulted in technical training for students (undergraduates and graduates) from the University of Delaware and the US Naval Academy and commercial staff providing new professional development.

Modular Autonomous Biosampler sea trials highlights

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rUi1Ah9lUlw

With the development and execution of this project we have generated a unique and highly capable modular autonomous biosampler that can sample multiple size classes and acts responsively to environmental stimulus for smart triggered sampling based on user defined parameters. The MAB was able to be configured and tested for multiple power and communication modalities including power over cable, battery power, and communications over fiber optical cable.

In the future the goals will be to reduce the size and complexity of the system based on the lessons learned in the development and field testing of the Modular Autonomous Biosampler with applications to extreme environment locations and autonomous platforms.
